DOC.HEAD: Plane Shot Down in Sudan, 4 Humanitarian Workers Killed
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with government accusing rebels of shooting down plane, U.N. comment, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A plane carrying four humanitarian workers from a southern Sudan town that is surrounded by rebels was shot down Thursday shortly after takeoff, and all aboard were killed, a United Nations source said. In the Sudanese capital of Khartoum, a statement by the Armed Forces General Command accused rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army of downing the plane with a Sam-7 missile. The U.N. source, who refused to be identified, said the twin-engine plane was headed for Khartoum from Aweil when it was downed by ground fire, the source said. Aweil, 590 miles southwest of Khartoum, is a government garrison town said to be surrounded by rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army. The source said three of the victims were French nationals, the fourth a Sudanese. He was unable to provide names, but said the doctor and nurse worked for Doctors Without Frontiers, a French organization. Officials at the Paris-based organization identified the dead as Yvon Feliot, a pilot working for the humanitarian group; Laurent Fernet, a supply specialist; and Jean-Paul Bescond, a doctor, all French nationals. The fourth was Frazer Ariyaba, a Sudanese technician for the World Food Program. The Sudanese army statement said the plane's four passengers were ``humanitarian messengers who devoted their lives to the service of man in his most difficult times.'' It said the downing of the plane was aimed at undermining peace efforts and destabilizing the country. The plane belonged to the Sudanese government, the U.N. source said. He said it was not clear what type of weapon was used to down the plane or who fired it. The rebels have been battling the Moslem-dominated government in Khartoum for six years in an effort to win greater autonomy and economic benefits for the largely Christian south. In New York, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he was grieved by the incident and called on the government and rebels to ``reinstitute a cease-fire and ensure safe passage for the humanitarian assistance.''
